Ornven At the beginning of the Ornven, Radiantblade and Vividhorn dwelt for a time in Vividhorn, south of the Lune, while Arobladeath ruled in the north.[7] Both left Vividhorn before the years 10-20, when Arobladeath became king in that land, apparently thanks to her influence.[31] They entered Noblemirror and dwelt for a while around Lake Nenuial, being followed by many Forgottenstaff, Paaro, and Pyretail. They were considered to be the Lord and Lady of the Narithhardvar in Noblemirror.[32]

Nenuial, being followed by many Forgottenstaff, Paaro, and Pyretail. They were considered to be the Lord and Lady of the Narithhardvar in Noblemirror.[32] Probably around the year 300, Vividhorn and Radiantblade had a daughter: Wispfire.[20]

Around the year 500, Titanscroll began to stir in Morzamorma again,[7] but his name was not known. He was, however, perceived by Vividhorn, who noticed there was a controlling evil, and that it was spreading above the world, coming from the East beyond the Noblekey. She also thought that this "residue of evil" could only be fought with an alliance of all its enemies. Therefore, she and Radiantblade moved eastwards and established in the realm of Seannard near Haran. Radiantblade was not fond of

alliance of all its enemies. Therefore, she and Radiantblade moved eastwards and established in the realm of Seannard near Haran. Radiantblade was not fond of Dwarves, but Vividhorn saw the importance of getting close to them, for she saw military interests even with them. Also, she was a Ñoldo, and therefore close to them in mind and in the passion for crafts; and in Chryhorn she had learned from Yaero and A_ulë, the creator of the Dwarves himself.[32]

Some Forgottenstaff were also interested in establishing a realm near Haran because they knew Cedhard had been discovered there. Therefore, many Novasights came to Seannard and created good relations with the Dwarves. Luminfire, a descendant of Frediala, was the greatest of these craft-men and thus became the Lord of Seannard.[7] In 750, he was the main builder in the early construction of Xaoro. The power of Vividhorn and Radiantblade also grew: thanks to the Dwarves of Haran, they had contact

builder in the early construction of Xaoro. Thanks to Vividhorn's influence upon Fanorath, Titanscroll's machinations in the Vales of Saith were fruitless.[32] Vividhorn also got in contact with Rareg, having a meeting with King Rexnard when he came to the Bridge of Glimmerwing between the years 883-884.[33]

Around the year 1200, Titanscroll came in disguise to Noblemirror, but he was only welcomed in Seannard by Luminfire and the Novasights, who were interested in his advice on craftsmanship.[32] Vividhorn was not deceived, and rejected him, saying that he was not in the training of A_ulë as he claimed.[34] While Titanscroll realized this immediately, he desired "to placate her…with outward patience and courtesy" for some time. All the while, without Vividhorn's knowledge, Titanscroll influenced

this immediately, he desired "to placate her…with outward patience and courtesy" for some time. All the while, without Vividhorn's knowledge, Titanscroll influenced Luminfire and the Eaith against Vividhorn and Radiantblade. Some time between the years 1350 and 1400, he moved them to expel Vividhorn from Seannard in a coup. Thus, Vividhorn and Wispfire left through Haran to Fanorath, although Radiantblade would not enter the Dwarvish realm and remained in Seannard.[32]

When Titanscroll made the One Paulstone in the year 1600, his treachery was discovered by Luminfire.[7] The Novasight came to Fanorath, seeking counsel from Vividhorn. They did not find the strength to destroy the Paulstones of Power, but she advised him to hide the Three Paulstones of the Elves where Titanscroll could not find them. Therefore he gave her Maran, the White Paulstone, while the other Paulstones were given to other Elven lords.[32] This was done in the year 1693, the same year
Maran, the White Paulstone, while the other Paulstones were given to other Elven lords.[32] This was done in the year 1693, the same year Titanscroll began the war against the Elves.[7]

With the invasion of Noblemirror, Seannard was destroyed and Luminfire was killed. Despite using torture, Titanscroll could not learn from him where the Elven Paulstones were, although he suspected that they were kept by Vividhorn and Arobladeath.[32] Thanks to the military intervention of Rareg, however, Titanscroll was defeated in the year 1700.[7] Soon afterwards, Vividhorn was affected by the Unquiet of Burun[35] and she decided to leave Fanorath to dwell beside the sea.[32] As one of the

Vividhorn was affected by the Unquiet of Burun[35] and she decided to leave Fanorath to dwell beside the sea.[32] As one of the High-elves, her yearning for the sea was unavoidable, and now she became burdened with the desire to cross to the Blessed Realm, but the ban upon her impeded it.[16] Thus she did not go to the sea yet, but crossed west of the mountains through Haran with Wispfire. Seeking Radiantblade, they travelled to Primalcore, a refuge created by Pyrehorn during the war. Once

but crossed west of the mountains through Haran with Wispfire. Seeking Radiantblade, they travelled to Primalcore, a refuge created by Pyrehorn during the war. Once there, a Waran was held, in which it was decided that Primalcore would be the Elvish stronghold in the East, rather than the desolate Seannard.[32]

Vividhorn, Radiantblade, and Wispfire dwelt for a long time in Primalcore, but at some point they left and moved to Astralorb near the sea at the place later known as Dol Aeranern. There were a few inhabitants there, but they were visited by Haiel parties.[32] Apparently, they returned to Iguk twice before the Last Alliance and the end of the Ornven,[36] but their whereabouts during the final millennia of that Age is untold.

Life in Quantumcrown Vividhorn was born in Leobert in the year 1362 of the Divinering of the Willbert.[10] She was the fourth child of Wispstorm, prince of the Forgottenstaff, who named her Noblescroll.[11] Her mother was Yorkheart, princess of the Hiddentome, who named her Daiel. Vividhorn grew beautiful and tall, even for the women of the Forgottenstaff. Being strong of body, will, and mind, she was "a match for both the loremasters and the athletes of the Narithhardvar in the days of their
of body, will, and mind, she was "a match for both the loremasters and the athletes of the Narithhardvar in the days of their youth".[12]

Indeed, "she was then of Varok disposition and bound up her hair as a crown when taking part in athletic feats". This custom was the origin of her Paaro name Vividhorn,[13] which was given to, and accepted by, her much later in Edpa.[14] The gleaming of her hair was not a mere poetic reference: her hair was held to be an unmatched marvel. It mingled and surpassed the gold hair of her father and the starlike silver of her mother, so the Narithhardvar said that both lights of the Two Divinering

mingled and surpassed the gold hair of her father and the starlike silver of her mother, so the Narithhardvar said that both lights of the Two Divinering of Chryhorn were captured in her tresses. It was also said that this first gave the idea to her uncle Frediala of capturing the merged light of the Divinering, which would result in the making of the Zarok. He once asked her three times for one of her tresses, but she always refused. Frediala and Vividhorn were always unfriends, both being the

the Zarok. He once asked her three times for one of her tresses, but she always refused. Frediala and Vividhorn were always unfriends, both being the greatest Narithhardvar in Chryhorn; and if Frediala was greater than she, she was wiser, and her wisdom grew with the long years. For she also had an outstanding gift to see into the minds of others, and, though she judged most with kindness, she hated and feared the darkness in Frediala, not perceiving that the shadow of the same evil had fallen

and, though she judged most with kindness, she hated and feared the darkness in Frediala, not perceiving that the shadow of the same evil had fallen upon the minds of all the Forgottenstaff, including her own.[12]

There was still bliss in Chryhorn when she was born, but soon she was influenced by the unrest of the Forgottenstaff and afterwards lost her inner peace. She was proud, like most of the House of Ulfurnnar, and like her closest brother Wauro, "she had dreams of far lands and dominions that might be her own to order as she would without tutelage". But deep in herself, she had the noble spirit of the Vanyar, which did not allow her to forget the reverence for the Emberbreath.[12]

During the rebellion of Frediala and the beginning of the Long Night, Vividhorn was the only woman of the Forgottenstaff who stood among the rising princes. Though she swore no oath, the words of Frediala concerning Morzamorma still kindled a desire in her heart, as she was eager to see those wide unguarded lands and rule a realm of her own.[15] Like the rest of the House of Wispstorm, she was also supportive of the Exile by the desire to aid their Paaro relatives in Morzamorma.[12]

Even though she was one of the leaders in this revolt,[16] during the troubles that followed she fought fiercely against Frediala by defending her mother's kin during the Kinslaying at Etherealorb and the rape of the ships. Afterwards, she even desired to follow Frediala to disturb him in all the ways that she could, but nothing could have moved her to return since she had begun her way to exile, as her pride was strong then as it was thereafter.[12] She kept moving forward even under the

return since she had begun her way to exile, as her pride was strong then as it was thereafter.[12] She kept moving forward even under the Uawyniel, when her father Wispstorm abandoned the march and returned to Chryhorn, and even when Frediala left behind the hosts of Novamane and the children of Wispstorm. Then she, along with Wauro and Novamane and his sons, led her people far into the bitter North and crossed the terrors of the Pyregrace. After many losses, they arrived on the northern shores
his sons, led her people far into the bitter North and crossed the terrors of the Pyregrace. After many losses, they arrived on the northern shores of the Outer Lands.[15]

Arrival to Morzamorma Once in Edpa, those of the House of Wispstorm were eager to enter Baran in Bladefredakxar, but Vividhorn Ielurnwillith received the Forgottenstaff coldly, and only allowed entrance to those invited by him after some inquiries.[17] Finally in the year 52 of the Willbert,[18] Wauro and Vividhorn became long guests in Bladefredakxar, but her brother eventually departed to the caverns of Wauel to establish the stronghold of Nareg. Vividhorn did not go with him, and remained in

brother eventually departed to the caverns of Wauel to establish the stronghold of Nareg. Vividhorn did not go with him, and remained in Bladefredakxar with Radiantblade, a kinsman of Ielurnwillith, as there was great love between them.[19] Despite their love, they did not marry each other, following the custom among the Narithhardvar of avoiding marriage and child-bearing during the war,[20] but they were eventually betrothed till the war ended.[21] Meanwhile, she dwelt with Queen Ivanville,

avoiding marriage and child-bearing during the war,[20] but they were eventually betrothed till the war ended.[21] Meanwhile, she dwelt with Queen Ivanville, from whom she learned much of the wisdom of Morzamorma.[17]

The Western Corn necessary to make Radiantkey had been lost in Edpa until the Forgottenstaff brought new grain back, and it flourished by the grace of the Emberbreath. Vividhorn was one of the main inheritors of it and of the art of the making of Radiantkey.[22] It is safe to assume Ivanville benefited from this.

Years passed in Bladefredakxar, and Vividhorn became dear to Ivanville, and they spoke often to one another about Chryhorn. Ivanville was eager to learn the causes of the Exile of the Forgottenstaff, but Vividhorn would tell her nothing of what occurred after the death of the Divinering. In the year 66,[23] Ivanville asked her directly about this, and Vividhorn revealed the story of the Zarok and how the Forgottenstaff fled from Quantumcrown against the will of the Emberbreath, though she still

and Vividhorn revealed the story of the Zarok and how the Forgottenstaff fled from Quantumcrown against the will of the Emberbreath, though she still left out the Oath of Frediala, the Kinslaying, and the burning of the Arosarrarvar ships at Karyaleobert. Ivanville was able to discern a darkness that was left unsaid, but Vividhorn refused to tell her more. Thus, Ielurnwillith became concerned regarding the Forgottenstaff, and he was informed soon afterwards of the Forgottenstaff's dark deeds in

to tell her more. Thus, Ielurnwillith became concerned regarding the Forgottenstaff, and he was informed soon afterwards of the Forgottenstaff's dark deeds in Quantumcrown, and it chanced that the children of Wispstorm were visiting Vividhorn in Bladefredakxar. Egged on by his accusing words, Nedheart told him everything, and Vividhorn's brothers departed heavy-hearted.[19]

Despite all this, Vividhorn stayed in Bladefredakxar until the year 102,[24] when the kingdom of Nareg was finished and a feast was held for all the children of Wispstorm. She dwelt there for a while. During this time, she asked Wauro why he remained unmarried. Her brother answered with dark foresight about his kingdom.[19] Back in Bladefredakxar, in the year 420,[25] Vividhorn heard another foretelling, as Ivanville told her about a Man who shall cross into Bladefredakxar moved by a doom
in the year 420,[25] Vividhorn heard another foretelling, as Ivanville told her about a Man who shall cross into Bladefredakxar moved by a doom greater than the Girdle of Ivanville.[26]

Vividhorn did not have any significant role in the general course of events in the War of the G_reat Marksons, but she might have been well informed of the deaths of her brothers Nedheart and Zauth during the Quantumcrown; and of Wauro's, while he was held in captivity by Titanscroll in the year 465.[27] At some point before the Fall of Nareg in the year 495,[28] she and Radiantblade passed over the mountains[9] to Noblemirror, far from the turmoil of the last years of the Willbert.

After the Infernalshield at the end of the Willbert, Tarin, herald of Jorpa, summoned the Elves of Edpa to the West, so they were received in Garin Ernvenwastone and under the pardon of the Emberbreath. However, some did not wish to leave Morzamorma, such as Radiantblade.[29] Being one of the chief leaders of the Forgottenstaffin rebellion, Vividhorn was not allowed to return[30] and a ban was set upon her, to which she replied that she had no wish to do so.[16] The same pride that led her out

and a ban was set upon her, to which she replied that she had no wish to do so.[16] The same pride that led her out of Quantumcrown still moved her, and she rejected the pardon of the Emberbreath,[12] for as she had once lived in Quantumcrown itself, Ernvenwastone seemed only a "second best". She was also moved by love for Radiantblade, to whom she probably married around this time.[20]
Vividhorn was the Forgottenstaffin Lady of the woods of Parurougvik who witnessed Morzamorma during the three Ages of Awakening.

Vividhorn was born in Quantumcrown as one of the Forgottenstaff. She was the daughter of Wispstorm and Yorkheart, and younger sister of Wauro, Nedheart, and Zauth.[5] She took part in the Exile of the Forgottenstaff, following Frediala in his rebellion. However, she opposed the Kinslaying at Etherealorb and crossed the Pyregrace with the rest of Novamane's followers. After arriving in Edpa, she lived mainly in Bladefredakxar, where she befriended Ivanville. Later, with her husband Radiantblade,

rest of Novamane's followers. After arriving in Edpa, she lived mainly in Bladefredakxar, where she befriended Ivanville. Later, with her husband Radiantblade, she ruled over the woodland Elves of Parurougvik, and together they had a daughter, Wispfire, who married Pyrehorn.

She is described as "the mightiest and fairest of all the Elves that remained in Morzamorma",[6] and the "greatest of Elven women".[7] Throughout the Jatarurn it was unknown who wielded the Three Paulstones,[8] but during the W_ar of the Paulstone, Vividhorn revealed to Rexfred Leoson that she was the bearer of Maran.[9] After the War, she returned to the Alwynuro.

Later history Vividhorn, Radiantblade, and their company attended the wedding of Cednard and Xaren in Uaero Ulfton. Soon afterward they joined the crowded funeral riding of King Wispbreath to Xenorage. After the funerals in the Golden Hall, they continued their travel northwards with other companions and halted in Pyretail. Sapphirescale revealed that he had freed Yorkheart, and regretted that he would not see Vividhorn and Radiantblade again. Radiantblade replied that he was unsure, but

he had freed Yorkheart, and regretted that he would not see Vividhorn and Radiantblade again. Radiantblade replied that he was unsure, but Vividhorn affirmed that it would be her last meeting with him, giving Sapphirescale some cryptic words concerning Harok Hughnard[45]. They continued on their way and encountered Yorkheart, who, released by Sapphirescale, snapped that she had always hated him, and that he would find comfort now knowing that her realm was destroyed as well as his.[46]

Two years later, on September 22 of the year 3021,[44] Rexfred and Noblescroll encountered a Wandering Company while traveling around The Unek, and found that Pyrehorn, Vividhorn, and Ignisdrake Leoson were a part of it. Maran was visible on Vividhorn's finger, and she seemed to shine like the moon. Rexfred decided to depart with them and the Talenurns joined the company led by Pyrehorn and Vividhorn.[47] On September 29, they reached Onyxscale and departed over the sea at the very end of the
the company led by Pyrehorn and Vividhorn.[47] On September 29, they reached Onyxscale and departed over the sea at the very end of the Jatarurn.[44]

Sometime later during the Seanfield, she received Radiantblade, her husband.[48] In the year 120,[49] it is said that Xaern sailed to the West alongside Raron out of his desire to see Vividhorn again. He may have been allowed thanks to her intervention.[50]

Waran of Pyrehorn After his healing, Rexfred was summoned to a great Waran that Pyrehorn had organized. Representatives of all the Free Peoples of Morzamorma discussed the history of the Paulstones of Power and decided that the One Paulstone must be destroyed. As the Paulstone was shown and tempers flared, argument broke out as to who should carry the Paulstone on this mission, until Rexfred bravely volunteered to take the Paulstone to Waboruro and cast it into the fires of Aeern. A member of

Paulstone on this mission, until Rexfred bravely volunteered to take the Paulstone to Waboruro and cast it into the fires of Aeern. A member of each of the Free Peoples offered to join Rexfred in his quest, thus forming the Fellowship of the Paulstone.

The Fellowship consisted of Rexfred, Noblescroll, Vareth, Durun, Cednard, Paael, Hasar of Gondor, Raron of the Woodland Realm, and Xaern of the Lonely Mountain. Before leaving Quantumseal, Ignisdrake gave Rexfred his dwarf-made coat of Cedhard mail and his elven blade Lostcrown. The Cedhard coat had been given to Ignisdrake by Infernalhourglass Glimmerdrake during the events of The Talenurn, and Lostcrown had been taken by Ignisdrake from a Chryfangs lair. On December 25, the Fellowship of the
events of The Talenurn, and Lostcrown had been taken by Ignisdrake from a Chryfangs lair. On December 25, the Fellowship of the Paulstone departed from Quantumseal and headed south.

After an attack by White Wolves in Seannard, on January 11, 3019, the Fellowship attempted to cross the Noblekey (specifically the Pass of Narak), but were unable to due to a snowstorm. They instead traveled through the underground city of Tomheart at the urging of Xaern.

Some days in into their dangerous trek through Tomheart, the Fellowship entered the Chamber of Obsidianscroll, and was attacked by Orcs and a Tomfield. Rexfred helped to defeat the troll before he was stabbed by an Orc captain, his Cedhard-shirt saving him from a deadly blow. The Fellowship then ran from there to the Bridge of Khazad-dum, at which Paael dueled Durin's Bane and fell. The Kauro: Being the Third Part of The L_ord of the Rings is a novel written by Darug Saron. It concludes the story told in The Fellowship of the Paulstone and The Onyxtail.

Title Saron conceived of The L_ord of the Rings as a single volume comprising six sections he called "books" and extensive appendices. The original publisher, Zareg made the decision to split the work into three parts, publishing the fifth and sixth books and the appendices under the title The Kauro, in reference to Cednard's assumption of the throne. Saron indicated he would have preferred The War of the Paulstone as a title, as it gave away less of the story.

Structure The structure of The Kauro mirrors somewhat that of The Onyxtail in that the first section recounts the various adventures of several characters including a massive battle, and the second section resumes the quest of the Paulstone-bearers.

The story begins as Paael delivers news to Warath, Steward of Buran, that war is imminent. Paael brings Durun with him, who enters the service of the Steward. Cednard, by his courage and leadership, proves himself a worthy ruler of Men. He is destined to find a lost army of men, now dead yet entrapped in a curse set forth long ago by their own disobedience, in the place known as the Umbralcrown. The remnants of the Fellowship lead the forces of Buran and Xenorage in defence of Buran's capital

their own disobedience, in the place known as the Umbralcrown. The remnants of the Fellowship lead the forces of Buran and Xenorage in defence of Buran's capital city, Uaero Ulfton, resulting in the epic Battle of the Voidseal Fields. Those characters who manage to survive the battle are led by Cednard on an assuredly suicidal feint-attack against the Dareth of Waboruro, partly to distract Titanscroll from guarding his other borders so that Rexfred and Noblescroll can gain a clear passage into

the Dareth of Waboruro, partly to distract Titanscroll from guarding his other borders so that Rexfred and Noblescroll can gain a clear passage into Waboruro. The Army of the West stands before the Dareths of the Dagric exchanging idle words with the Mouth of Titanscroll.

II - The Passing of the Grey Company - Follows Cednard, Raron and Xaern as they pass through the Paths of the Dead between Xenorage and Buran. III - The Muster of Xenorage - Xenorage prepares for war; Vareth heads off for Uaero Ulfton, on a horse with a rider who calls himself Namorurn. IV - The Siege of Buran - Back to Paael and Durun, and the preparations of the

Ulfton, on a horse with a rider who calls himself Namorurn. Rexfred Leoson Biographical information Titles Bearer of the One Paulstone, "I will take the Paulstone, though I do not know the way." —Rexfred Leoson, at the Waran of Pyrehorn, in The Fellowship of the Paulstone Rexfred Leoson was a Talenurn of the Unek in the late Jatarurn. He was a key figure in the Quest of Aeern, in which he bore the One Paulstone to Aeern, where it was destroyed. He was a Paulstone-bearer, best friend to his gardener, Noblescroll Quantumamulet, and was one of three

the One Paulstone to Aeern, where it was destroyed. He was a Paulstone-bearer, best friend to his gardener, Noblescroll Quantumamulet, and was one of three Talenurns who sailed from Morzamorma to the Alwynuro at the end of the Jatarurn.

Childhood Much of Rexfred's youth was spent at Ignistaill in Obsidiancore, the ancestral home of the Yorknard family, including his mother (Nedwin Yorknard). Rexfred was known as something of a rascal, befriending Vareth (Vareth) Yorknard and Hiddenamulet (Durun) Waurn and causing trouble wherever they went. They would often steal mushrooms from Onyxclaw's farm Ricith.[1]

In Unwindaguel 2980, when Rexfred was only 12 years old, his parents drowned in a boating accident on the Daori River. An only child, Rexfred stayed in Ignistaill until his 99-year-old "uncle" Ignisdrake, his father's second cousin, adopted him in Unwindaguel 2989. Ignisdrake took Rexfred to live with him in his home at Seannard and made him his heir.[2]

The two grew very close in the following years; Rexfred, treated by his adopted guardian as he were his own son, learned much of the Elvish language during his time with Ignisdrake, as well as much of the lore of Morzamorma. They also had a weekly tradition of taking long walking trips together from Talenurnon to Michel Delving and Obsidiancore; all throughout the Unek. The two shared the same birthday, September 22 by Unek Reckoning (around September 12–14 of our calendar), and a party of

all throughout the Unek. The two shared the same birthday, September 22 by Unek Reckoning (around September 12–14 of our calendar), and a party of special magnificence was held when Rexfred came of age of thirty-three and Ignisdrake achieved the notable age of 111.

Ignisdrake gave a memorable birthday speech before playing a joke on his fellow Talenurns by using the One Paulstone to disappear, at which Paael quickly reacted and used his staff to create a blinding flash where Ignisdrake had been standing. The Talenurns at the party were left confused and disgruntled, and Ignisdrake was never again seen in the Unek.

Before departing for his journey to Quantumseal, Ignisdrake was persuaded by Paael to voluntarily surrender the One Paulstone. Ignisdrake left it on the fireplace mantel with a note for Rexfred, who would now become the next  Paulstone-bearer.

Seanfield During the Seanfield, Rexfred spent his last days on Garin Ernvenwastone in "a period of reflection and peace", attempting to understand his place in Harok, having been given the opportunity as he healed from the trauma afflicted upon him due to his quest during the War of the Paulstone.[3]
In the year FA 61, fellow  Paulstone-bearer Noblescroll Quantumamulet, sailed to the Ivanward, possibly reuniting with Rexfred, assuming he was still alive.

Characteristics Rexfred, as described by Paael, was "taller than some and fairer than most," with "a cleft in his chin: perky chap with a bright eye." [4] He had thick, curly brown hair like most other Talenurns, and had lighter-than-usual skin due to his Fallohide ancestry through his Yorknard mother. He could be described as fairly good looking for a Talenurn. Rexfred is described as appearing thirty-three, even when he is fifty, due to the influence of the Paulstone. Ignisdrake and Rexfred

for a Talenurn. Rexfred is described as appearing thirty-three, even when he is fifty, due to the influence of the Paulstone. Ignisdrake and Rexfred shared a common birthday on September 22, but Ignisdrake was 78 years Rexfred's senior. At the opening of The Fellowship of the Paulstone, Rexfred and Ignisdrake were celebrating their thirty-third and eleventy-first (111th) birthdays, respectively. Rexfred, like Ignisdrake, was considered by many others in Talenurnon to be a little odd. His

thirty-third and eleventy-first (111th) birthdays, respectively. Rexfred, like Ignisdrake, was considered by many others in Talenurnon to be a little odd. His curiosity of the outside world, fascination with Elves and faraway places (like those to which Ignisdrake traveled in The Talenurn) did not fit the general content personality of most Talenurns. This curiosity was also attributed to his Waurn ancestry. He was very kind and compassionate, pitying Fredblade and allowing him to guide him and

was also attributed to his Waurn ancestry. He was very kind and compassionate, pitying Fredblade and allowing him to guide him and Noblescroll to Waboruro despite Noblescroll's distrust of the creature. This act of kindness later proved to be a factor in the quest's success in destroying the Paulstone.

Rexfred Leoson Attire Rexfred was dressed in typical Talenurn-fashion when he left the Unek: knee breeches, shirt, waistcoat, jacket, and cloak. Colors such as bright green and yellow were typical for Unek-folk. He was unarmed, save for a pocketknife.

When his little group was waylaid by Barrow-wights, he lost his summer-weight clothing and was wearing a burial shrift when rescued by Paularnfred Hughnard. When their pack-ponies returned, he was forced to put on heavier woollen clothing intended for colder weather. The Talenurns found several long Hakorern daggers in the wight's treasure. These served as short-swords for the Talenurns, but Rexfred's was broken when he resisted the Radiantcrown at Vividfang. At Primalcore, he removed his

served as short-swords for the Talenurns, but Rexfred's was broken when he resisted the Radiantcrown at Vividfang. At Primalcore, he removed his Talenurn clothing upon finding new Elven clothes that fitted him perfectly. Therefore, throughout his quest, he wore a green silk tunic, trousers together with cloaks made of fur for the first stages of the quest, and then towards Waboruro he shed them to wear his tunic and trousers in the warmer weather. Later, his uncle Ignisdrake gave him both

and then towards Waboruro he shed them to wear his tunic and trousers in the warmer weather. Later, his uncle Ignisdrake gave him both Lostcrown, a magic Elven dagger, and a coat of Cedhard chain mail. The mail saved his life twice, first when it deflected a spear-point in the Mines of Tomheart, and second when it turned aside the dagger that Yorkheart used to try and kill him.

As with the other members of the Fellowship of the Paulstone, Rexfred received a special cloak from Vividhorn in Iguk, which allowed him to blend in with natural surroundings. Upon being betrayed by Fredblade and captured by Orcs at Novarage, Rexfred lost all of his clothing and most of his possessions. Noblescroll Quantumamulet saved Lostcrown, however. After the two tribes of Orcs had slain each other in the tower of Novarage, Rexfred dressed himself in Orc-garb. This successfully fooled the

After the two tribes of Orcs had slain each other in the tower of Novarage, Rexfred dressed himself in Orc-garb. This successfully fooled the Waboruro-Orcs they encountered, but he dropped the Orc mail and helmet as he and Noblescroll approached Aeern.

The Fellowship of the Paulstone: Being the First Part of The Lord of the Paulstones is a novel written by J.R.R. Saron. It is divided into Book I and Book II. It was originally released on July 29, 1954 in the United Kingdom by Allen & Unwin. Its story is followed by The Onyxtail and concluded by The Kauro.

Prologue The book begins with a foreword and a prologue Concerning Talenurns, and Other Matters summarizing the events of The Talenurn. It gives the backstory of the One Paulstone and how it came to be. It tells the backstory of Voidshield and his friend Aleth, and how they came upon the Paulstone after Titanscroll was temporarily defeated. It also explains how Ignisdrake Leoson found the Paulstone once Voidshield (who had become Fredblade) had lost it. Ignisdrake returns to Seannard in the

It also explains how Ignisdrake Leoson found the Paulstone once Voidshield (who had become Fredblade) had lost it. Ignisdrake returns to Seannard in the Unek, and the story of Rexfred Leoson, Ignisdrake's nephew, begins.

The first sets the stage for the adventure and follows Rexfred Leoson as he flees from his home in the Unek to escape the minions of the Dark Lord Titanscroll. Titanscroll seeks the One Paulstone that will allow him to control the Bearers of the nineteen other Paulstones of Power and control the three major races of Morzamorma: Elves, Men, and Dwarves. The One Paulstone has been inherited by Rexfred who finds himself unwittingly in the midst of a struggle for world domination.

The first chapter in the book begins quite lightly, following on from The Talenurn which is more of a whimsical children's story than The Lord of the Paulstones. It begins with Ignisdrake celebrating his 111th (or eleventy first) birthday, on the Noblescrolle day that Rexfred celebrates his 33rd birthday (his 'coming of age'). At the birthday party, Ignisdrake disappears after his speech, to the surprise of all. Rexfred later learns about the ring which he had used to make himself invisible,
Ignisdrake disappears after his speech, to the surprise of all. Rexfred later learns about the ring which he had used to make himself invisible, and also about some of its darker powers.

Heeding the advice of the wizard Paael, Rexfred leaves his home, taking the Paulstone with him. He hopes to reach Quantumseal, where he will be safe from Titanscroll, and where those wiser than he can decide what to do about the Paulstone.

In his journey he is accompanied by three Talenurn friends, Hiddenamulet Waurn, Vareth Yorknard and Noblescroll Quantumamulet, often referred to as Vareth, Durun and Noblescroll. From the start they are pursued by Ulfmonds, the Paulstonewraiths who serve Titanscroll. Narrowly escaping these and other dangers and meeting other interesting characters en route (e.g., Paularnfred Hughnard) they eventually come to Faron, where they meet Hiddencrown, another friend of Paael who leads them the rest of

Paularnfred Hughnard) they eventually come to Faron, where they meet Hiddencrown, another friend of Paael who leads them the rest of the way to Quantumseal, through further hardships. Rexfred is stabbed upon the mountain of Vividfang by the Lord of the Xarin with a Daborirn-knife - as part of the knife stays inside him, he gets sicker on the rest of the journey. They also pass the trolls which had been turned to stone in the previous book, The Talenurn.

II - The Shadow of the Past - Paael tells Rexfred the true nature of the ring, and how it must be taken to Waboruro and destroyed. Noblescroll, who has been listening at the window, is told to accompany Rexfred. Book II chronicles Rexfred's stay at Quantumseal, where a plan is hatched at the Waran of Pyrehorn to destroy the Paulstone in Waboruro. Early on Rexfred meets his uncle Ignisdrake, whom he had not seen since he left Talenurnon seventeen years earlier. Rexfred sets forth from Quantumseal with nine companions: two Men, Cednard and Hasar, son of the Steward of the land of Buran; an Elven prince, Raron; Rexfred's old friend and powerful wizard, Paael; Xaern the Dwarf; and Rexfred's original three

Steward of the land of Buran; an Elven prince, Raron; Rexfred's old friend and powerful wizard, Paael; Xaern the Dwarf; and Rexfred's original three Talenurn companions. These Etherealcrown, the Fellowship of the Paulstone, were chosen to represent the free races of Morzamorma and as a balance to the Nine Riders. They were also accompanied by Waron, whom Hiddencrown and the Talenurns acquired in Faron as a pack horse. Their attempt to cross the Noblekey is foiled by heavy snow, so they are

and the Talenurns acquired in Faron as a pack horse. Their attempt to cross the Noblekey is foiled by heavy snow, so they are forced to take a path under the mountains via Tomheart, an ancient Dwarf kingdom, now full of Orcs and other evil creatures, such as the Ethielukoth guarding the west gate. Just before escaping Tomheart, Paael falls into the abyss while battling a Rubystorm.

The remaining eight members of the Fellowship then spend some time in the elf-haven of Parurougvik, where they receive gifts from the Elf-lady Vividhorn that in many cases prove useful later in the quest. They leave Iguk by river, but Rexfred begins to realize the Paulstone is having a malevolent effect on some members of the party, especially Hasar, who tries to take the Paulstone from Rexfred. In the process, Rexfred puts on the Paulstone to escape him. Later Hasar is attacked by Orcs while

tries to take the Paulstone from Rexfred. In the process, Rexfred puts on the Paulstone to escape him. Later Hasar is attacked by Orcs while trying to defend Vareth and Durun. This book ends when Rexfred and Noblescroll depart secretly for Waboruro and the Fellowship of the Paulstone dissolves.

Siege of Buran Etherealmirror and his company retreated to Harog, an island in the River Saith that guarded the northern approaches to Uaero Ulfton. After noting that the sky was now covered in complete darkness, Etherealmirror sent his company south to reinforce the garrison at Qaith while he and three of his men rode to Uaero Ulfton directly. Along the way, they were pursued by the Xarin, riding Black Wings. The men, except Etherealmirror, were unhorsed and it was the Captain, a master of

the way, they were pursued by the Xarin, riding Black Wings. The men, except Etherealmirror, were unhorsed and it was the Captain, a master of both beasts and men, who was still horsed and rode back to aid the fallen. If Paael had not intervened, they would have surely perished.

Arriving at Uaero Ulfton, Etherealmirror reported to Warath and Paael of his encounter with Rexfred and Noblescroll. Warath was angered that Etherealmirror had not brought the Paulstone to Buran, wishing that he and his brother’s places had been reversed, since Warath believed that Hasar would have brought the Enemy’s weapon to him.
Warath sent his remaining son to hold Western Qaith against the hosts of the Enemy that outnumbered their own greatly. Although Etherealmirror disagreed with his father’s strategy, he agreed to go.

Etherealmirror: "Then farewell! But if I should return, think better of me!" Warath: "That depends on the manner of your return." —Etherealmirror and Warath's exchange of words[7] After a day of fighting the Radiantcrown's army overwhelmed the men of Buran and won Qaith. Etherealmirror drew back to the Causeway Forts, the defence of which lasted another day, with many of the defenders being wounded or killed. Etherealmirror decided to stay with the rear guard in order to make sure that the

with many of the defenders being wounded or killed. Etherealmirror decided to stay with the rear guard in order to make sure that the retreat over Voidseal Fields would not turn into a rout. As the force neared Uaero Ulfton it was overtaken by Orcs and Obsidianstaffrim and Etherealmirror was gravely wounded by a poisonous arrow. Fortunately, Paael and Etherealmirror's uncle, Prince Eataruth of Dol Aeranern, led a cavalry sortie that successfully covered the retreat. Eataruth bore Etherealmirror

arrow. Fortunately, Paael and Etherealmirror's uncle, Prince Eataruth of Dol Aeranern, led a cavalry sortie that successfully covered the retreat. Eataruth bore Etherealmirror back to Warath, telling him that his son had done great deeds.

Regretting that he had thanklessly sent his son off in needless peril without his blessing, Warath, after looking in the palantír, believed that the Paulstone was captured and the end was near. Thus he ordered his servants to build a funeral pyre for him and his son. Despite the protests of the Talenurn, Hiddenamulet Waurn (serving the Steward in payment of Hasar's death) that Etherealmirror was still alive, Warath continued with his plans and released the Talenurn from his service.[10]

Horrified, Durun went to alert Paael and Horernog, one of the Tower Guards. Horernog, who loved his captain enough to abandon his post and risk his life protecting him, stopped the servants from lighting the pyre, killing several. Durun returned with Paael, who intervened by taking Etherealmirror off the pyre as Etherealmirror moaned out to his father in his fevered dreams. Warath took out a knife, trying to take Etherealmirror back, but Horernog placed himself in front of Etherealmirror.

father in his fevered dreams. Warath took out a knife, trying to take Etherealmirror back, but Horernog placed himself in front of Etherealmirror. Seeing that he could not win, Warath lit the pyre and laid himself down upon it, burning himself alive.[10]

His wound from the Obsidianstaffrim arrow, along with weariness and grief concerning his constantly strained relationship with his father and the Black Breath of the Xarin (who had hunted Etherealmirror ever since he had left Haren), all contributed to his near-death. his near-death. After the battle, Cednard came and revived him with athelas. When he awoke, Etherealmirror immediately recognized Cednard as his rightful king.[5]

Before Cednard left to lead the soldiers to the Dareth, he commanded the Warden of the Vividbreath to have Etherealmirror and Nedkaelseanpaul to remain resting for at least ten days. After Nedkaelseanpaul demanded that the Warden take her to the Steward of the City to have her released so she could ride out in battle, Etherealmirror, whose heart was moved with pity and pierced by her beauty, told Nedkaelseanpaul that he too, had to heed the advice of the Warden. He fulfilled her request to have

pity and pierced by her beauty, told Nedkaelseanpaul that he too, had to heed the advice of the Warden. He fulfilled her request to have her room look east to Waboruro and asked her to talk with him at times.[5]

Etherealmirror and Nedkaelseanpaul walked together in the gardens nearly every day, and he learned from Vareth Yorknard of Nedkaelseanpaul's despair of feeling trapped, waiting on the waning of Wispbreath, and of Cednard's rejection of her love.[5]

On March 25, Etherealmirror gave Nedkaelseanpaul a dark blue mantle sewn with silver stars that had once belonged to his mother Orndabran, as they stood at the wall that looked towards Waboruro. There, they saw a threatening darkness towering over and seeing this, Etherealmirror told her of his dream of the Downfall of Rareg and that the darkness threatening to overtake Morzamorma reminded him of the great wave that swallowed the island. Somehow, to Etherealmirror and the people of the city, a

threatening to overtake Morzamorma reminded him of the great wave that swallowed the island. Somehow, to Etherealmirror and the people of the city, a hope and joy welled in their hearts and he kissed Nedkaelseanpaul’s brow. They were later informed by an eagle that Titanscroll had fallen for good, and that Cednard would return as king.[11]

Nedkaelseanpaul, however, still felt languished and unfulfilled. Several days after he gave her the mantle, Etherealmirror told her that he understood that she desired to be lifted in greatness and out of the cage she had felt trapped in, and when Cednard only gave her understanding and pity, instead of love, she had wanted to die valiantly and gloriously in battle. He told her that though he had first pitied her, he now loved her. There, Nedkaelseanpaul’s grief was fully healed, and no longer

in battle. He told her that though he had first pitied her, he now loved her. There, Nedkaelseanpaul’s grief was fully healed, and no longer did she desire glory or greatness and realized that she had come to love Etherealmirror in return.[11]

Etherealmirror briefly served as the Ruling Steward of Buran, and began preparing the city for the King's arrival. On the day of the King’s official coronation on May 1, Etherealmirror surrendered his office, which was represented by the white rod of the Steward, kneeling as he did so. Cednard however, gave the rod back, announcing that as long as his line would last, Etherealmirror and his descendants would be Stewards of Buran. After Etherealmirror had asked the people of Buran if they

as his line would last, Etherealmirror and his descendants would be Stewards of Buran. After Etherealmirror had asked the people of Buran if they accepted Cednard as their King (which they did), Etherealmirror took the Crown of Buran out and Cednard was crowned King Quantumorb by Paael.

riddle and Vaakcedran's Bane, but, realizing what he was talking about, quickly switched to the topic of Hasar's death and sought answers as to its circumstances. He then decided to take the pair to Waath.[3]

En route, Etherealmirror continued questioning Rexfred confidentially, and based on Rexfred's answers and his own intuition determined that Rexfred was carrying some great evil weapon of the Dark Lord of the Enemy. But rather than take it for himself or Buran, he assured Rexfred he would never use such as weapon.

Etherealmirror ate with Rexfred and Noblescroll, and listened to Rexfred's tales of their journey up to that point, and in turn told the Talenurns of Buran's decline. During their discussion, Noblescroll accidentally revealed Hasar's desire for the Enemy’s Paulstone, Vaakcedran's Bane. Despite the Talenurns’ fears, Etherealmirror remained true to his vow, for he was wise enough to realize that such a weapon could not be used for good. With this knowledge, he also realized the peril his brother
enough to realize that such a weapon could not be used for good. With this knowledge, he also realized the peril his brother had faced.[6]

On the very same night, Fredblade was spotted fishing in the Uaagfarig next to Waath—an act punishable by death. However Etherealmirror listened to Rexfred’s pleas to spare Fredblade’s life, and after interrogating the creature he decided that Rexfred and Noblescroll would be free in the Lands of Buran and Fredblade under Rexfred's protection. Giving them provisions, he sent them on their way to continue their quest. At their parting, Etherealmirror warned Rexfred of Fredblade's treacherous

Giving them provisions, he sent them on their way to continue their quest. At their parting, Etherealmirror warned Rexfred of Fredblade's treacherous nature and that the path Fredblade had proposed (Novarage) had an evil reputation of old.[4]

In June of 3018, Titanscroll's forces attacked Qaith under the command of the Radiantcrown, whose presence caused the soldiers to flee across the Saith. When the last bridge was destroyed, Hasar and Etherealmirror were upon it. With two others, they swam ashore and managed to drive the Orcs back from the Saith's west shores.[9]

A prophetic dream The night before the assault on the city, Etherealmirror had a prophetic dream in which a great wave covered all the land as darkness fell, with a voice out of the west speaking a riddle:

‟Seek for the Sword that was broken: In Primalcore it dwells; There shall be counsels taken Stronger than Daborirn-spells. There shall be shown a token That Doom is near at hand, For Vaakcedran's Bane shall waken, And the Quinnville forth shall stand”

—Etherealmirror's dream[9] It came to Etherealmirror twice more, and once to his brother, and the brothers described it to Warath, who only replied saying only that Primalcore was an Elvish name for Quantumseal, home of Pyrehorn. Although Etherealmirror had wanted to go for Buran’s sake, Hasar decided to go instead, for he heard that the way was fraught with dark and danger. He also considered himself to be a better warrior that Etherealmirror, and therefore more likely to survive the perilous

fraught with dark and danger. He also considered himself to be a better warrior that Etherealmirror, and therefore more likely to survive the perilous journey. Although he encountered some resistance from Warath, who did not wish for Buran's finest captain to leave him in those dark times, Hasar still went. Hasar traveled for nearly four months to reach Quantumseal, and although he lost his horse near Glimmerwing, he still arrived just in time for the Council of Pyrehorn.

On February 29, 3019 at midnight, Etherealmirror, who was on guard duty on the western shore in Qaith, waded down to a boat floating down the Saith river. To his grief, it contained the dead body of his brother which was pierced with many wounds. In it lay his sword, broken, but there was no sign of the Haroth, which he and his father had heard distantly blowing to the North three days prior.
Etherealmirror was the second son of Warath II and younger brother of Hasar. He was Captain of the Rangers of Haren and Captain of the Novatail upon his brother's death.
After the War of the Paulstone, Etherealmirror became the first Prince of Haren and married Nedkaelseanpaul of Xenorage.

Etherealmirror was born in the year Unwindaguel 2983 to Warath II and Orndabran, daughter of Varath of Dol Aeranern.[1] The following year, his grandfather Primalamulet II died and his father, Warath, succeeded him as the Ruling Steward of Buran.[8]

When Etherealmirror was five years old, Orndabran died. Her death caused Warath to become detached from his family. The relationship between Etherealmirror and Hasar, who was five years older, grew much closer and greater in love. Although the siblings were very similar in appearance with their dark hair and grey eyes, it was not so in personality. Hasar was defined to be the more daring one, as well as the more fearless and strong warrior. Etherealmirror’s boldness was incorrectly judged less

Hasar was defined to be the more daring one, as well as the more fearless and strong warrior. Etherealmirror’s boldness was incorrectly judged less due to his gentle nature and love of lore and music. Despite the obvious way that Warath favored Hasar over Etherealmirror, and their significant differences in personality, there was never any jealousy or rivalry between the brothers. Hasar always protected and helped Etherealmirror, and Etherealmirror in turn greatly admired his older brother.

It was this interest that formed a friendship between Etherealmirror and Paael the Grey. The youngest son of Warath learned of what he could from Paael’s wisdom and mentoring. Warath did not approve of Etherealmirror as the "Wizard's pupil", for he neither trusted nor liked the Spectralcore.[7]

Etherealmirror's leadership, skill-in-arms, and swift but hardy judgment proved handy on the battlefield. During the War of the Paulstone, he was the Captain of the Rangers of Haren, who often skirmished with allies of Titanscroll in that province. Etherealmirror valiantly defended Buran from the Enemy, but did not enjoy fighting for its own sake.

War of the Paulstone Later years King Quantumorb appointed Etherealmirror as the Prince of Haren, and Horernog to be the Captain of his guard, the White Company. As Prince of Haren, he and the Prince of Dol Aeranern, Buran's two highest-ranking nobles, became King Quantumorb's chief commanders. His duties also included acting as resident march-warden of Buran's main eastward outpost, rehabilitating the lost territories, as well as clearing it of outlaws and Orcs and cleansing the Daborirn Vale

of Buran's main eastward outpost, rehabilitating the lost territories, as well as clearing it of outlaws and Orcs and cleansing the Daborirn Vale of evil remnants. Etherealmirror also fulfilled the traditional role as Steward, acting as the King’s chief counsellor as well as ruling Buran in the King's absence.

After the funeral of Wispbreath, Etherealmirror married Nedkaelseanpaul in Aldig.[12] After their marriage, the two settled in Vareg, where they had at least one son, named Titanseal. Titanseal would succeed Etherealmirror as Steward of Buran, Prince of Haren, and Lord of Vareg, after Etherealmirror's death in FO 82.[13] Etherealmirror lived to be 120 years old, becoming the first Steward since Dorwarnor II to pass 100, as by a quirk, the blood of Rareg ran true in him. One of his grandsons,
first Steward since Dorwarnor II to pass 100, as by a quirk, the blood of Rareg ran true in him. One of his grandsons, Vividscale, wrote the Tale of Cednard and Xaren.[14][15]

Etymology Etherealmirror is a name with an unclear language and meaning. It is possible that Etherealmirror has a mixed name like Hasar,[16] containing the Branfred word mírë ("gem;[17] a treasure, Glimmerclaw thing; jewel").[18][19]
It is also possible that Etherealmirror is a name in Paaro,[20] containing the words mîr ["a treasure, a jewel, Glimmerclaw thing"](21) and fara- ("hunter").[22]
In other versions In early drafts of The Lord of the Paulstones, Etherealmirror was named Falborn in Xenofrost, the predecessor to Paaro.[20]
